Common Expressions: What's up? What's the matter? [lit., What is he/she/it doing?]
Who are you? What is your name?
Excuse me. I didn't mean to.
Don't do it. Leave it alone. Don't bother him/her [to one person].
I don't want to! Ouch! That hurts! That's too bad!
Too bad! What a shame! It's no good!
Watch out! Danger! It's scary [refers usually to physical danger].
It's warm! [usually of a building or clothing].
How nasty, ugly, bad, wrong! [expression of dislike, disapproval].
What in the world is he/she doing?
Look! Look right here! Look over there!
Listen to that noise [of something unseen].
It's too big, too much! He/she is very big!
What are you doing? How are you doing?
How is your wife/husband? He/she is fine.
And your children, how about them? // They've been sick.
How are your relatives? // They're fine.
Why did you come here? // For no particular reason.
Is Nauyaq here? // She's not here.
See you tomorrow again. // See you later.
Come in [to one person]. // Come in [to many people].
Go out [to one person]. // Go out [to many people].
Come with me [to one person]. // Come with me [to many people].
Help me [to one person]. // Help me [to many people].
Take it out [to one person]. // Take it out [to many people].
Take it, pick it up [to one person]. // Take it, pick it up [to many people].
Give it here [to one person]. // Give them here [to one person].
Eat [to one person]. // Eat [to many people].
Eat it [to one person]. // Eat it [to many people].
Don't eat [to one person]. // Don't eat [to many people].
Drink it [to one person]. // Drink it [to many people].
Throw it out [to one person]. // Throw them out [to many people].
Turn on the light [to one person].
Turn out the light [to one person].
Get it out of the way [to one person]. // Get it out of the way [to many people].
Get out of the way, move [to one person]. // Get out of the way, move [to many people].
Take off your parka, coat [to one person]. // Take off your parka, coat [to many people].
Take off your boots [to one person]. // Take off your boots [to many people].
Sit down [to one person]. // Sit down [to many people].
Wait for me [to one person]. // Wait for me [to many people].
Come here [to one person]. // Come here [to many people].
Get up [to one person]. // Get up [to many people].
Go to bed [to one person]. // Go to bed [to many people].
Go away [to one person]. // Go away [to many people].
Don't touch it [to one person]. // Don't touch it [to many people].
Come again [to one person]. // Come again [to many people].
Don't forget [to one person]. // Don't forget [to many people].
Don't forget it [to one person]. // Don't forget it [to many people].
Wake up [to one person]. // Wake up [to many people].
Move [to one person]. // Move [to many people].
Please say it again [to one person].
Don't get into things. Don't dig around in things.
What shall we do? / Let's go to the basketball game. / Let's go fishing.
What are you going to do? / What do you want to do? / I want to go to the basketball game. / I want to go fishing.
What are you doing? / I'm making Eskimo ice cream. / I'm reading. / I'm sewing. / I'm washing dishes.
Sumik niġiñiaqpisa? / Maktaŋmik. / Paniqtamik. / Quamik.  / Iqaluŋmik.
What shall we eat? / Muktuk /  Dried fish or meat. / Frozen fish or meat. / Fish.
Sumik niġisukpich? / Qaqqiamik. / Asianik. / Akutumik. / Qaqqulaamik.
What do you want to eat? / Bread. / Berries. / Eskimo ice cream. / Pilot bread.
Sumik pisukpich? / Saviŋmik. / Atigimik. / Ulumik. / Aglautmik.
What do you want? / A knñe. / A parka. / An ulu. / A pencil or pen.
Where are you going? / To the store. / To the school. / To the meeting.
Where are you staying? / At the hotel. / At the school. / With Pakik and family.
Where are you from? / I'm from Noatak. / I'm from Kotzebue. / I'm from Barrow. / I'm from Nome.
Where are you coming from? / From the school. / From my house. / From the airport.
Qaŋa aglaan aggiqpich? / Unnuaq aggiqsuaŋa. / Uvlaaq.
When did you come? / I came last night. / This morning.
How long will you be here? / One week. / All winter. / One month.
What are you going to do here? / I'm going to work. / I'm going to study.
When are you going home? / Tomorrow. / Day after tomorrow.  / In a few days.
Who are your parents? / Qapuk and Aŋutvak.
Qitunġaqaqpiich? / Ii, malġuŋnik. / Piŋasunik. / Sisamanik. / Tallimanik.
Do you have any children? / Yes, two. / Three. / Four. / Five.
Kia una pia? / Una pigigiga. / Una pigigaa Aqim. / Una pigigiñ.
Whose is this? / This is mine. / This is Aqi's. / This is yours.
Kia ukua piŋi? / Ukua pigigitka. / Ukua pigigai Aqim. / Ukua pigigitin.
Whose are these? / These are mine. / These are Aqi's. / These are yours.
Kiña aakan? / Aakaga Qapuk. / Qapuk aakagigiga.
Who is your mother? / My mother is Qapuk. / Qapuk is my mother.
Kiña aapan? / Aapaga Niksik. / Niksik aapagigiga.
Who is your father? / My father is Niksik. / Niksik is my father.
Aanan (ataatan) iñuuva suli? / Ii, iñuuruq aglaan utuqqaġuqtuq.
Is your grandmother (grandfather) still living? / Yes, he/she is alive but has gotten old.
Where do you work? / I work at the school. / At the hospital.
When are you leaving? / I leave tomorrow. / On Wednesday.
Utiġniaqpich iḷaatni? / Ii, upinġaaqpan utiġniaqtuŋa. / Ukiaġun.
Will you(1) come back some time? / Yes, I'll come back next summer. / Next fall.
Do you eat Native food? / Yes, I like to eat maktak. / But I don't like fermented whale meat.
How much does that cost? / It costs a dollar. / It costs a quarter.
Do you understand me? / Yes, when you speak slowly. / No, I don't understand you.
Nakuaġiviuŋ una? / Ii, nakuaġigiga. / Naagga, nakuaġiŋitkiga.
Do you like this? / Yes, I like it. / No, I don't like it.
May I go with you? / Go ahead.
How should I do it? / Like this. / Like that.
Who is this? / Niksik. / My father.
What kind of hot drink do you want? / Coffee. / Tea.
What is this in Iñupiaq? / A chair.
How do you say "wolverine" in Iñupiaq? / We say, "qapvik."
Are you hungry? // I'm hungry. / I'm not hungry.
Do you want to eat? // I want to eat. / I don't want to eat.
Are you sleepy? // I'm sleepy. / I'm not sleepy.
Are you tired? // I'm tired. / I'm not tired.
Are you sick?  // I'm sick. / I'm not sick.
Do you have a headache? // I have a headache. / I don't have a headache.
Do you want a hot drink? // I want a hot drink. / I don't want a hot drink.
Are you cold? // I'm cold. / I'm not cold.
Are your feet cold? // My feet are cold. / My feet are not cold.
Are you hot? // I'm hot. / I'm not hot.
Do you have a stomachache? // I have a stomachache. / I don't have a stomachache.
Are you lonely? // I'm lonely. / I'm not lonely.
Are you happy? // I'm happy. / I'm not happy.
Are you homesick? // I'm homesick. / I'm not homesick.
Aŋutvak and Qapuk are my parents(2).
We(2) are cross-cousins [meaning that our parents are brother and sister].
What is your older sister's Eskimo name?
What is your younger sibling's English name?
Are you married? [lit., do you have a spouse?]
How many children do you have?
Tallimanik qitunġaqaqtuuŋa, piŋasunik aŋutinik aasii malġuŋnik aġnaŋnik.
I have five children, three boys and two girls.
Are you older than I am?
No, I am turning twenty. I'm younger than you.
aġnaq // Una aġnaq nuliaġiviuŋ? / Ii, nuliaġigiga.
woman // Is this woman your wife? /Yes, she is my wife.
boat // We(2) are going to Sisualik in my boat.
house // Do you have a house in Sisualik?
tent // No, I have a tent.
school // My aunt teaches Iñupiaq at the school.
child, offspring // How many children do you(2) have?
small child // The children are being rambunctious.
store/ /How many stores are there in Kotzebue?
church // Is it time to go to church?
river  // Noatak is on a big river.
sea, ocean // My parents(2) are fishing at the beach (seashore).
airport // Can you take me to the airport?
land // The land up there has lots of berries.
lake // The lakes up there have sourdock.
mosquito // In summer there are lots of mosquitoes here.
airplane // Airplanes go to Sisualik oñen.
rifle // What kind of rifle do you have?
rain // Is it going to rain?
Iñupiaq Eskimo // Do you speak Iñupiaq to your grandmother?
Naluaġmiu // Naluaġmiu kaviqsaanik nuyaqaqtuq. // Iñupiat Naluaġmiuraalaitchut iŋiḷġaan.
white person, English // The white person has red hair.  // The Iñiupiat people didn't speak English long ago.
husband // My husband likes to eat muktuk.
wife // My wife sews a lot.
daughter // Is your daughter in college?
son // Her son is a good hunter.
What is your job in Kotzebue?
I teach at the school. / I'm a doctor at the hospital.
Where do you want to go eat?
Let's(2) go to the Nullaġvik Hotel.
Do you want to come to my house? I have some fish.
I like fish. What kind are they?
trout / sheefish / small whitefish / chum salmon
That's fine, thank you very much.
Do you want to spend the night at our house?
I won't be here. I have to leave this evening.
When you come back, please stay here.
I'll be back for the quarterly meeting in March.
It's time to go. Thank you for letting me eat.
Tell your wife I say hello.
Is there a telephone here? / There is a telephone at the store.
Naami tauqsiġñiaġvik? / Naŋirvium saaŋaniittuq. Atlanik tauqsiġñiaġviqaqtuq unani taġium siñaani.
Where is the store? / There is one in front of the hospital. There are other stores down by the waterfront.
What is it like? Is it red? / Yes, it's red.
Where is the post office? / It's nearby. That's it over there.
Where's the school? / Up that way, across from the college.
Where's the Senior Center? / It's down that way, just this side of the A.C. store.
The Friends' Church is located the other side of the Napa store.
When it becomes warmer I will fetch some wood.
When the weather becomes nice, I will go out with a dog team.
When the west wind blows, it's always cold.
When the weather becomes warmer, I will go hunt seals.
It's time for shee fishing in March.
They will have a dog race up to the Kobuk River.
John Baker usually runs the dog races.
It's almost spring time around here.
When it becomes warm, some of the people go camping.
They usually go camping on the ocean beaches.
Iḷaŋich iñuich savaktuat aŋuniaġuurut umianik Qikiqtaġruŋmiñ.
Most of the people who have jobs hunt with boats from Kotzebue.
one // I have one older sister.
two // I have two younger siblings.
eight // Give me eight of them.
ten // Ten women sang on Sunday.
qulit atausiq // Qulit atautchimik iqaluktuq aŋun.
eleven // The man caught eleven fish.
qulit malġuk // Qulit malġuk qipmich qimuktut.
twelve // Twelve dogs are pulling a sled.
qulit piŋasut // Qulit piŋasunik kigvaluktuq aapa.
fourteen // I have fourteen students in my class.
fifteen // I found fifteen wild eggs.
akimiaq atausiq // Paniga akimiaq atausimik ukiuniktuq.
sixteen // My daughter turned sixteen years old.
seventeen // Seventeen people are going to Barrow.
akimiaq piŋasut // Qavsiuvat tuttut? Akimiaq piŋasut.
eighteen // How many caribou are there? Eighteen.
nineteen // My shoes(2) cost nineteen dollars.
twenty // We have twenty fingers and toes.
twenty-one // I paid him twenty-one dollars.
iñuiññaq qulit / Tatqiq iñuiññaq qulinik uvluqaqtuq.
thirty // A month has thirty days.
forty // I cried hard when I turned forty.
sixty // Are you sixty years old?
one hundred // One hundred people arrived by airplane.
thousand // More than a thousand people live in Kotzebue.
Nuurvik // Nuurviŋmiittuŋa. // Nuurviŋñiaqtuŋa. // Nuurviŋmiñ aggiqsuŋa. // Nuurviŋmiuŋuruŋa.
Noorvik // I'm in Noorvik. // I'll go to Noorvik. // I'm coming from Noorvik. // I'm from Noorvik.
Nuataaq // Nuataamiittutin. // Nuataaġniaqtutin. // Nuataamiñ aggiqsutin. // Nuataaġmiuŋurutin.
Noatak // You're in Noatak. // You'll go to Noatak. // You're coming from Noatak. // You're from Noatak.
Ipnatchiaq // Ipnatchiamiittuq. // Ipnatchiaġruaqtuq. // Ipnatchiamiñ aggiqsuq. // Ipnatchiaġmiuŋuruq.
Deering // He/she is in Deering. // He/she will go to Deering. // He/she is coming from Deering. // He/she is from Deering.
Ambler // Will you(2) go to Ambler?
Sheshaalik // My mother and I will go to Sheshaalik tomorrow.
Point Hope // I arrived from Point Hope this morning.
Barrow / My daughter went to Barrow yesterday.
Siberia or Siberian person/The Siberians came to dance.
When will you travel to Shungnak?
I won't be going to Shungnak. I'll go to Noorvik.
What will you do in Noorvik?
No, she/he is staying home with the children.
Do you have friends in Noorvik?
My cross-cousin and family live in Noorvik.
How far is it from Kotzebue?
Thirty minutes tiŋmiñaqtuq, aasii aputikuaġutikun piŋasut sassaġniġmi.
It's thirty minutes by airplane or three hours by snowmachine.
Are there lots of fish in Noorvik in the Kobuk River?
Yes, there are trout, sheefish, salmon, and northern pike.
Noorvik is on a bluff on the banks of the Kobuk.
Is there another village close to Noorvik?
Yes, Kiana isn't far. It's on the Kobuk too.
How long will you be gone?
spring // In spring we go out to camp on the coast.
summer // In summer we fish and it's hot.
autumn // In autumn we hunt caribou.
winter // In winter it's windy and cold.
It's five o'clock. // It's past five o'clock.
It's almost time for geese to arrive.
I will come over when I'm done.
We will go to Larry's place at seven o'clock.
I will return to Fairbanks in the morning.
There will be Eskimo games tonight.
Days of the week (Inupiaq names for the days are not used very often, and English names are used instead.)
Savaiḷiq, Savalliiḷiq, Ilaqatchiiḷiq, Qitchiiḷiq, Sisammiiḷiq, Tallimiiḷiq, Itchaksriiḷiq
Sunday, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday, Saturday
Uvlupak Savaitchugut (Savalliuqtugut, Ilaqatchiuqtugut, Qitchiurugut, Sisammiuqtugut, Tallimiuqtugut, Itchaksriuqtugut).
Today is Sunday (Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday, Saturday).
berry // The berries are really good. // Give me some berries.
salmonberry // The salmonberries are plentiful. // I want to go pick salmonberries.
blueberry // Blueberries are blue. // I want to eat blueberries.
paunġaq // Paunġat taaqtaaŋurut. // Paunġat nakuurut akutumi.
blackberry // Blackberries are dark in color. // Blackberries are good in Eskimo ice cream.
dried fruit // Dried fruit can be cooked.
piece of large fruit, like apple, orange // Apples, oranges don't grow in Alaska.
Eskimo ice cream // My mother makes Eskimo ice cream. // Do you like Eskimo ice cream?
loaf of bread // I want to buy some loaves of bread. // Do you want some bread to eat?
stew // The stew is already salted. // I am making stew.
pilot bread // Children like to eat pilot bread. // We eat pilot bread with stew.
dried fish // We eat dried fish with dinner. // We make dried fish in summer.
cooked partially dried salmon // I eat half-dried salmon with seal oil. // Half-dried salmon are good as leftovers.
coffee // My mother makes coffee in the morning. // Would you like coffee?
saigu // Saigu una isuqtuq. // Saigumik yuuqqaġuktuŋa.
tea // This tea is brewed strong. // I would like to drink some tea.
hot drink // Would you like a hot drink? // The men want a hot drink.
water // The water is cold. // Don't spill the water.
coffee maker // Is there coffee still in the coffee maker?
bed // Move the bed. / Make the bed for them.
light // Turn the light on. / Turn the lights off.
semi-circular knife, ulu // Give me the ulu.
curtain or shade // Draw the curtain [over the window].
door // Close the door. / The door is open.
pot // I will make soup in the pot.
mop // The mop is hanging up.
salmon // Is there any salmon around here?
trout // Trout make good frozen fish.
tomcod // In the fall they hook for tomcod through the ice.
smelt // I love to eat smelt.
caribou // They have gone caribou hunting.
bearded seal // We dry the bearded seal meat.
walrus // Walrus often wash up on the beach.
beaver // He has a beaver hat.
wolf // Wolves also make good ruffs.
muskrat // I have a muskrat parka.
ground squirrel // My dog hunts ground squirrels.
bird, duck, goose // Birds lay their eggs around here in the springtime. ·
hawk // Hawks arrive the very first [of all the birds in spring].
seagull // Seagulls usually arrive early [in spring].
pintail duck // Pintail ducks have bugs.
Arctic tern // Arctic terns are noisy.
sandhill crane // Cranes have long legs.
oldsquaw [long-tailed] duck // Oldsquaws are found in lakes.
black brant goose // Black brants make good soup.
snowy owl // Some people eat snowy owl.
common snipe // It's good to hear the common snipe.
eagle // The giant eagles of long ago must be extinct.
What do you want to eat?
Thank you, I haven't eaten Eskimo food in a long time.
My son here will prepare [and cut] some frozen fish and meat.
When you don't have any Eskimo food, you really crave it.
Then I will fix a sack [of food] for you.
It's good to have close friends.
It would be very good indeed to have some berries.
Call me when you plan to come here sometime.
For your information, I will come here again next year.
Good, we will eat together again then.
Hello. Come in, please. Here is a chair.
I have an appointment at one o'clock.
How is Bubba doing in school?
Nakuuruq, kisirrutit nakuaġigai, aglaan Uaatni agliqisupialaitchuq.
Very good, he likes math, but sometimes does not really like to read.
I read to him at home all the time.
There are books here if you would like to bring some home.
That's okay, we have all kinds of books.
Will you continue to read to him?
Yes, I want him to be able to comprehend his reading.
Very good. I will call or let you know when his reading improves.
You finally came, and what might you be here for?
I'm looking for some small nails.
I want to build a grub box.
Over there by the door [are nails].
And do you have any hinges?
They're across there, behind the brooms.
Do you have cartridges for a twenty-two rifle?
My son is going squirrel hunting tomorrow.
They are in there with the clothing.
There are none. They haven't come in yet.
Here is some strong rope which has just arrived.
There are lots of squirrels at Salluq.
Who made that parka? It has nice trim.
I'd like to buy it for my wife. It's her birthday tomorrow.
Do you know my grandmother Suuyuk? She's my neighbor. She's a good seamstress.
Let me pay now. What is the total cost?
I'm going camping at Pipe Spit tomorrow.
Who else will be going along?
Myself, some children, and some elders.
How will you(3+) go to camp?
How many boats will you(3+) take?
The tents are already there. We all have sleeping bags.
Is the food all ready? Are the boats loaded?
There's lots of food for the journey down on the beach.
What will you(3+) all do at camp?
First, we'll set a net for trout.
When we catch fish, we'll cut them to make dried fish.
And we'll go hunt sea mammals [seals and walruses] when the ice is good.
When we catch seals, we'll butcher them.
We will also make seal oil from the blubber.
When the fish and meat are dry, we will store them.
Are you going to teach the children how to do this?
Yes, the elders want to teach the chikiren.
Call me on the CB radio when you arrive, so that we won't worry.
In the spring, we hunt for wild eggs.
Where do you go to hunt eggs?
My spouse and I are going to the Chamisso Islands.
How do they hunt eggs? Do you have to climb up?
Ii, mayuġnaqtuq, suli iḷaatni qauyaġnaqsisuuruq sialukman.
Yes, you have to climb and sometimes it gets slippery when it rains.
What kinds of eggs are there?
Murres and lesser gulls [smaller than seagulls] nest in the cliffs there.
What else is on the island?
There is sea lovage and wild celery on top of the island; they grow tall.
I would like to go along some time.
Yes, but I will have to watch you closely. It's dangerous when you don't know [the place].
And there is white gravel on the mainland beach.
It's white and they use it when they take the fur off the ugruk hide when making hard soles for mukluks.
First they put it on the fur side [of the mukluk bottom] and then they scrape off the fur.
That's great, I've learned something more.
The eggs must be boiled [before they are eaten].
Some people store them in seal oil in pokes.
You can bake a cake using only one egg.
It makes it [the cake] rise a lot.
It's way better than with store-bought eggs.
Wow, they sure eat good food.
We hardly hunt for molting ducks around here.
But there are molting ducks where there are no people.
A long time ago there used to be some in Anigaaq.
There used to be molting ducks there in the grass.
How about now, are they gone?
They're gone. They are over where there's not much traffic.
